title: Retroperitoneal Sarcoma
diagnosis_topic: Retroperitoneal Sarcoma – Diagnosis, Staging, and Surgical Management
setup_script: “A 60-year-old man presents with progressive abdominal fullness and early satiety. He reports a 15-pound weight loss over the past 2 months. On exam, you palpate a large, firm, non-tender abdominal mass extending across the left flank and abdomen. Bowel sounds are present. How would you proceed?”

dynamic_flow.reply: - “CT abdomen/pelvis with contrast shows a 20 cm heterogeneous retroperitoneal mass displacing the left kidney and descending colon, without clear invasion. No distant metastases are seen. What is your next step?”
- “An open biopsy is performed, traversing multiple tissue planes. Pathology: high-grade liposarcoma. What are the implications of this biopsy approach?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident suggests image-guided core biopsy
dynamic_flow.reply: - “CT-guided core needle biopsy shows high-grade dedifferentiated liposarcoma. What is your management plan?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident proceeds directly to surgery without biopsy
dynamic_flow.reply: - “You proceed with laparotomy. You encounter a massive retroperitoneal tumor adherent to the left kidney and descending colon. What is your operative plan?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident performs en bloc resection
dynamic_flow.reply: - “You perform complete en bloc resection including the left kidney and segment of colon. Margins are negative. What is your plan for postoperative management?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident fails to mention multidisciplinary planning
dynamic_flow.reply: - “Given the complexity of this case, how should multidisciplinary care be incorporated?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about role of radiation therapy
dynamic_flow.reply: - “What is the role of preoperative vs postoperative radiation therapy in retroperitoneal sarcoma?”
- “What is the role of chemotherapy in primary retroperitoneal sarcoma?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident fails to discuss surveillance
dynamic_flow.reply: - “How would you structure surveillance following complete resection of a 20 cm retroperitoneal sarcoma?”
- “The patient re-presents 12 months later with recurrent disease involving the retroperitoneum and new pulmonary nodules. How would you manage this?”

critical_decision_points: Recognition of retroperitoneal mass as possible sarcoma
Use of CT imaging for diagnosis and surgical planning
Appropriate biopsy technique (image-guided core vs avoiding poorly placed open biopsy)
Principles of en bloc resection with adjacent organs if needed
Limited role of radiation and chemotherapy in retroperitoneal sarcoma
Importance of multidisciplinary planning (surgical oncology, radiation oncology, medical oncology)
